entry.title: Streamlined Kyma deployment for CAP applications
entry.content:
SAP BTP, Kyma runtime (a fully managed cloud-native Kubernetes application runtime based on the open-source "Kyma" project) enables developers to deploy highly scalable, modular, and secure microservices. The SAP Cloud Application Programming (CAP) model supports Kyma deployments as one of the recommended approaches in the SAP BTP Developer‚Äôs Guide

What‚Äôs New

In the November release of CAP, we have introduced several key improvements that significantly simplify the deployment of CAP applications to Kyma.

Here is a quick look at the changes:

  1. Streamlined project setup: The new cds add kyma command quickly configures your Kyma project and serves as the central entry point for configuring deployments to Kyma.
  2. Interactive credential handling: When using cds up -2 k8s, you‚Äôll receive prompts for any missing registry credentials on your Kyma cluster, eliminating guesswork during deployment.
  3. Automatic UI5 build: The cds up -2 k8s command now automatically builds your SAP UI5 applications, removing an extra manual step from your workflow.
  4. Intelligent build optimization: Builds now trigger only when artifact changes are detected, eliminating unnecessary build cycles and notably speeding up your deployment process.
  5. Simplified tooling: The standalone containerize tool (also known as ctz) is no longer required. The cds up -2 k8s command handles containerization directly reducing external dependencies

Ready to try it out? Make sure to have the latest cli version with npm i -g @SAP/cds-dk@latest, also check out the updated documentation  and our release notes for complete details on these improvements.

As always, if you have any questions, do not hesitate to reach out to us on cap@sap.com

entry.title: Determining the Right Owner in SAP Sales Cloud V2 Using Account Hierarchy
entry.content:
Sales teams work best when every opportunity, lead, or order lands in the hands of the right person. The challenge is that ownership isn‚Äôt always straightforward. Accounts have parent-child relationships. Territories change. Local teams handle one part of the business while regional teams oversee the rest. And when ownership isn‚Äôt assigned correctly, work slows down, follow-ups slip, and revenue gets left on the table.

SAP Sales Cloud V2 now includes a new determination step that tackles this neatly: Owner determination based on the Account Hierarchy. It‚Äôs simple in concept but hugely practical in day-to-day sales operations.

 

What this new determination step does

When a user creates a transaction‚Äîan opportunity, lead, quote, order, or similar‚Äîthe system looks for the owner directly on the account. That part is unchanged.

The new behavior kicks in when the account itself doesn‚Äôt have an assigned owner. Instead of stopping there or relying on manual intervention, the system now:

  1. Checks the account.

  2. If there‚Äôs no owner, moves one level up in the account hierarchy.

  3. Continues climbing to the parent, then the parent‚Äôs parent, all the way to the top.

  4. Stops as soon as it finds an owner.

  5. Assigns that owner to the transaction.

This gives companies a way to define ownership at the level that actually makes sense for their structure‚Äîwhether that‚Äôs a subsidiary, a sub-division, or the global parent.

Why this matters

Here‚Äôs the thing. Many organizations have thousands of accounts, often organized into complex hierarchies. Maintaining individual owners at every level is unnecessary work. Teams end up doing manual corrections when ownership isn‚Äôt found or is outdated.

This new feature removes that burden.

It makes ownership deterministic, predictable, and aligned with the real business structure.
If a subsidiary doesn‚Äôt have a local sales rep assigned, the regional or global account manager automatically takes over. No gaps. No inconsistencies. No manual fixes.

A real-world example

Let‚Äôs look at a fictional company setup.

Example company: NovaTech Industries

NovaTech operates globally and has several regional subsidiaries.

  • NovaTech Global (Top Account)

    • NovaTech Europe

      • NovaTech Germany

        • NovaTech Berlin Office

      • NovaTech France

    • NovaTech APAC

      • NovaTech Japan

NovaTech assigns owners like this:

  • NovaTech Global: Sarah Kim, Global Account Director

  • NovaTech Europe: Lukas Steiner, Regional Sales Lead

  • NovaTech Germany: No owner assigned

  • NovaTech Berlin Office: No owner assigned

Now imagine a sales rep creates an opportunity for NovaTech Berlin Office. Before this enhancement, the system wouldn‚Äôt find an owner and might skip assignment or require manual correction.

With the new determination step activated:

  1. System checks NovaTech Berlin Office ‚Üí no owner

  2. Moves to NovaTech Germany ‚Üí still no owner

  3. Moves to NovaTech Europe ‚Üí owner found (Lukas Steiner)

  4. Opportunity owner is set to Lukas automatically

No confusion. No backlogs. The transaction immediately flows to the right responsible person.

What this really means?

This new determination step closes one of the long-standing gaps in ownership assignment for transaction documents. It helps organizations keep data cleaner, removes dependence on manual fallbacks, and ensures every lead or opportunity is routed correctly even when account-level maintenance isn‚Äôt perfect.

The outcome is simple.
Sales teams spend less time fixing ownership issues and more time moving deals forward.

If you rely heavily on account hierarchies, activating this step can bring immediate clarity and reduce errors‚Äîespecially in fast-scaling businesses or distributed sales organizations.

entry.title: RAG vs CAG: Choosing the Right Knowledge Augmentation Strategy for LLMs
entry.content:
Cache-Augmented Generation offers a compelling alternative to RAG's retrieval pipeline‚Äîeliminating latency overhead and achieving up to 40x faster generation times‚Äîbut context window constraints limit its applicability to smaller, static knowledge bases. For data scientists evaluating these approaches, the choice hinges on a fundamental trade-off: CAG delivers superior speed and slightly higher accuracy for manageable datasets, while RAG remains the only viable option for enterprise-scale deployments with dynamic, evolving knowledge. The emergence of hybrid architectures in 2024-2025 now enables organizations to capture the benefits of both approaches through intelligent query routing

 

Introduction

Large Language Models have transformed how organizations interact with information, but their static training data creates a fundamental limitation: they cannot access current information or proprietary knowledge bases. This knowledge gap has driven the development of augmentation techniques that extend LLM capabilities by grounding responses in external data sources.

Retrieval-Augmented Generation emerged in 2020 as the dominant paradigm, combining information retrieval with text generation to enable LLMs to answer questions using custom document collections. The RAG ecosystem has since matured substantially, spawning an entire ecosystem of vector databases, embedding models, and orchestration frameworks. Yet according to industry analyses, approximately 72% of enterprise RAG implementations either fail outright or deliver significantly below expectations in their first year [1], prompting researchers to explore alternatives.

Cache-Augmented Generation represents a paradigm shift introduced in late 2024. Rather than retrieving relevant documents at query time, CAG preloads entire knowledge bases into the LLM's extended context window and caches the computational state for reuse across queries. This approach eliminates the retrieval pipeline entirely, promising simpler architectures and faster response times. Understanding when to deploy RAG, CAG, or hybrid approaches has become essential for organizations building knowledge-intensive AI applications.

 

What is RAG?

Retrieval-Augmented Generation is an AI framework that enhances Large Language Models by combining information retrieval with text generation. Instead of relying solely on knowledge encoded during training, RAG retrieves relevant information from external knowledge bases at inference time and incorporates it into the generation process.

The foundational paper, "Retrieval-Augmented Generation for Knowledge-Intensive NLP Tasks," was published by Patrick Lewis and collaborators at Facebook AI Research (now Meta AI) in May 2020 [2]. The researchers combined a pre-trained parametric memory (the seq2seq model BART) with non-parametric memory (a dense vector index of Wikipedia), demonstrating state-of-the-art results on open-domain question-answering tasks.

 

 

 

Core Architecture and Workflow

RAG systems operate through two distinct phases. The indexing phase occurs offline before any queries are processed: documents are loaded from various sources, broken into smaller chunks, converted into vector embeddings using models like OpenAI's text-embedding-3-small, and stored in vector databases such as SAP HANA. This preprocessing transforms unstructured documents into a searchable semantic index.

The inference phase activates when users submit queries. The system converts the query into a vector embedding using the same model that processed the documents, searches the vector database for semantically similar chunks, ranks the retrieved results by relevance, and constructs an augmented prompt combining the original query with retrieved context. The LLM then generates a response grounded in the provided information. A typical prompt structure instructs the model: "Using the CONTEXT provided, answer the QUESTION. Keep your answer grounded in the facts of the CONTEXT. If the CONTEXT doesn't contain the answer, say you don't know."

The RAG ecosystem has matured substantially since 2020. Orchestration frameworks like LangChain and LlamaIndex simplify pipeline construction.

 

Issues and Drawbacks of RAG

Despite widespread adoption, RAG systems face significant challenges across latency, accuracy, implementation complexity, and operational maintenance that explain the high enterprise failure rate.

 

Latency Overhead Compounds with Each Component

RAG introduces substantial performance penalties. Research published in December 2024 found that RAG-unique components account for 36-45% of end-to-end latency, with retrieval alone comprising 41% of response time [3]. In aggressive retrieval configurations, RAG overhead can reach 97% of total latency, pushing response times to approximately 30 seconds [3].

 

The "Lost in the Middle" Problem Undermines Long-Context Retrieval

Stanford and University of Washington researchers identified a critical accuracy issue: LLMs exhibit a U-shaped performance curve when processing retrieved context [4]. Performance is highest when relevant information appears at the beginning or end of the context window but degrades by more than 20% when key information falls in the middle. This persists even in models explicitly designed for long-context processing. The root cause traces to rotary position embedding introducing long-term decay that causes models to prioritize tokens at sequence boundaries.

 

Seven Documented Failure Points Reveal Systemic Vulnerabilities

Empirical research identified seven distinct failure modes in RAG systems [5]. Missing content occurs when answers simply don't exist in the knowledge base, yet the system generates plausible-sounding responses. Missed top-ranked documents happen when correct answers exist but don't rank highly enough to be retrieved within the top-K limitation. Consolidation failures arise when retrieved documents don't make it into the final context due to token limits. Extraction failures occur when the LLM fails to identify answers amid noisy or contradicting retrieved content.

 

Implementation Complexity Creates Combinatorial Tuning Challenges

Practitioners face what industry analysts describe as a "combinatorial explosion" of parameters requiring joint optimization: chunk size and overlap, embedding model selection, vector database configuration, top-K retrieval settings, reranking algorithms, context consolidation strategy, and prompt engineering. Finding optimal chunking strategies proves particularly difficult‚Äîchunks that are too small cannot answer certain questions, while chunks that are too large introduce noise.

 

Accuracy Degrades at Scale

Research by EyeLevel.ai found that vector similarity search precision degrades starting at 10,000 pages, with 12% accuracy loss by 100,000 pages [6]. As datastores grow, retrieval throughput can degrade significantly, presenting challenges for enterprise-scale deployments.

 

What is CAG?

Cache-Augmented Generation represents an alternative paradigm that bypasses real-time retrieval entirely. Introduced in December 2024 by Brian Chan, Chao-Ting Chen, Jui-Hung Cheng, and Hen-Hsen Huang in their paper "Don't Do RAG: When Cache-Augmented Generation is All You Need for Knowledge Tasks," [7] CAG leverages the extended context windows of modern LLMs to preload entire knowledge bases rather than retrieving subsets at query time.

 

 

The Three-Phase CAG Workflow

CAG operates through three distinct phases. During knowledge preloading, a curated collection of documents is preprocessed and formatted to fit within the model's context window. The LLM processes this collection, generating a precomputed Key-Value (KV) cache that encapsulates the inference state. This cache is stored persistently on disk or in memory, with computational cost incurred only once regardless of subsequent query volume.

During inference, the precomputed KV cache is loaded alongside each user query. The LLM utilizes this cached context to generate responses directly‚Äîno dynamic document fetching occurs. The combined prompt provides unified understanding of both knowledge and query, enabling the model to reason across the entire knowledge base simultaneously.

The cache reset phase addresses a practical concern: since KV caches grow in an append-only manner as new tokens are generated, resetting involves truncating newly appended tokens to return to the original cached state. This enables rapid reinitialization without reloading the entire cache from disk.

 

Understanding the KV Cache Mechanism

CAG extends the standard KV caching concept by precomputing the entire KV cache for the knowledge base‚Äînot just conversation history‚Äîand storing it persistently. At inference time, loading this pre-computed cache makes the "context" effectively free from a computational perspective. The model treats the entire knowledge base as if it were part of the conversation history, enabling full-context reasoning without retrieval.

 

Model Requirements for CAG Deployment

CAG requires long-context LLMs to be practical. Current frontier models supporting extended contexts include Google's Gemini 2.5 Pro and Flash with 1-2 million token windows, Claude models supporting 200K-1M tokens, GPT-4o with 128K tokens, and open-source options like Llama 3.1 with 128K token support. Research indicates that most models experience performance degradation before reaching advertised limits‚Äîa 128K window typically remains reliable to approximately 100K tokens in practice.

 

How CAG Addresses These Challenges

CAG's architectural simplicity eliminates several of RAG's fundamental pain points while introducing its own trade-offs.

 

Latency Reduction Through Retrieval Elimination

By removing the retrieval pipeline entirely, CAG achieves dramatic latency improvements. The original CAG paper demonstrated generation times of 0.85 seconds versus 9.25 seconds for small HotPotQA datasets‚Äîa 10.9x speedup [7]. For larger datasets (64 documents, 85K tokens), CAG completed in 2.33 seconds compared to 94.35 seconds without caching, representing a 40.5x improvement [7]. These gains come from eliminating query embedding computation, vector similarity search, document reranking, and context packaging steps that dominate RAG latency.

 

Accuracy Improvements from Complete Context Access

CAG consistently achieves higher accuracy than RAG configurations across benchmark datasets. On HotPotQA, CAG achieved BERTScore of 0.7759 versus 0.7516 for the best dense RAG configuration [7]. On SQuAD datasets, CAG scored 0.8265 compared to 0.8035 for dense RAG [7]. The advantage becomes more pronounced for multi-hop reasoning tasks requiring information synthesis across multiple documents‚ÄîCAG has access to all documents simultaneously, while RAG may miss connecting information if the retriever fails to surface relevant chunks.

RAG particularly struggles with queries requiring multi-step reasoning, general queries where formulating retrieval queries is difficult, and implicit queries requiring whole-context understanding.

 

Architectural Simplicity Reduces Failure Modes

CAG eliminates several RAG failure points entirely. There are no retrieval misses because all documents are always present. Chunking strategy optimization becomes unnecessary. Embedding model selection and vector database tuning disappear as concerns. The combinatorial explosion of RAG parameters collapses to a simpler question: does your knowledge fit within the context window? This simplification reduces implementation time, operational complexity, and the surface area for system failures.

Empirical benchmarks reveal that neither approach dominates across all dimensions‚Äîthe optimal choice depends on specific deployment requirements.

Scalability represents CAG's fundamental constraint. When researchers attempted CAG with 500+ documents on HotPotQA, the system encountered token limit errors [7]. RAG maintains consistent accuracy through selective retrieval regardless of total corpus size, making it the only viable option for enterprise knowledge bases spanning millions of documents.

 

Limitations of CAG

Understanding CAG's constraints is essential for appropriate deployment decisions.

 

Context Window Ceiling Creates Hard Knowledge Limits

Even with models supporting 128K or 1M token contexts, CAG cannot accommodate enterprise-scale knowledge bases. Web-scale corpora like Wikipedia's 3 billion words remain entirely infeasible. A 128K token window accommodates approximately 300 pages of text‚Äîsubstantial for focused applications but insufficient for organizations with multi-terabyte document repositories.

 

Memory and Compute Requirements Are Substantial

The KV cache grows linearly with context length and can exceed the size of model weights themselves at long contexts. Researchers reported that dual A100 40GB GPUs couldn't handle CAG scaling to larger knowledge bases, with the initial loading process proving "extremely memory-intensive." Standard attention has O(n¬≤) complexity, making very long inputs computationally prohibitive. Production deployments often require 8-way tensor parallel setups across multiple GPUs to support both long contexts and reasonable concurrency.

 

Static Knowledge Creates Freshness Challenges

CAG's precomputed cache reflects knowledge at a single point in time. For dynamic domains‚Äînews, market data, legal compliance updates, inventory systems‚Äîcached knowledge becomes stale rapidly. Rebuilding caches for large knowledge bases requires substantial compute overhead, making CAG unsuitable for applications requiring dynamic updates or on-demand knowledge integration.

 

The "Lost in the Middle" Problem Persists

Despite having full context access, CAG inherits the same positional bias affecting all long-context LLM processing. Research confirms that information positioned in the middle of long contexts is more likely to be overlooked or poorly utilized, producing a U-shaped accuracy curve regardless of whether context arrived through retrieval or preloading [4].

 

Hybrid Approaches Combining CAG and RAG

The recognition that neither approach dominates across all scenarios has driven development of hybrid architectures that capture benefits from both paradigms.

 

 

Self-Route Enables Adaptive Query Handling

Research presented at EMNLP 2024 introduced Self-Route, an approach where the LLM self-reflects on whether queries are answerable with RAG alone [8]. The system presents retrieved chunks to the model, which evaluates whether the context is sufficient. If answerable, the system uses the lower-cost RAG response; if insufficient, it escalates to full long-context processing. For Gemini-1.5-Pro, 81.74% of queries were answered by RAG without escalation, achieving performance comparable to full long-context processing while using only 38.6% of tokens [8].

 

Tiered Architectures Serve Diverse Query Patterns

Organizations are implementing tiered systems that route queries based on characteristics. Core, frequently-accessed knowledge is preloaded via CAG for instant response times. Extended or dynamic knowledge is served through RAG with real-time retrieval. A retail example preloads product specifications via CAG for customer support while using RAG to fetch current promotions or inventory status. This architecture balances the efficiency of preloading with the flexibility of retrieval, enabling sub-second responses for common queries while maintaining access to the full knowledge corpus.

 

Foundation Context with Selective Retrieval

The original CAG paper proposed systems that "preload a foundation context and use retrieval only to augment edge cases or highly specific queries" [7]. This balances efficiency with flexibility‚Äîstable knowledge lives in the cache while the retrieval system handles novel or specialized information needs. The RAPTOR approach extends this by clustering documents into topics, generating high-level summaries for each cluster, caching summaries in the CAG layer, and fetching full documents on demand when deeper detail is required [9].

 

Conclusion

The emergence of Cache-Augmented Generation challenges assumptions that have dominated knowledge-augmented AI development since 2020. For applications with manageable, stable knowledge requirements where latency matters, CAG offers a compelling alternative: 10-40x faster generation times, 2-4% higher accuracy, and dramatically simpler architecture compared to RAG. The elimination of retrieval pipelines removes entire categories of failure modes that have frustrated enterprise deployments.

Yet RAG remains indispensable for the majority of production use cases. When knowledge bases span millions of documents, when information changes frequently, or when source attribution is required, RAG's selective retrieval approach proves essential.

The most significant development is the maturation of hybrid architectures that transcend the binary choice. Self-Route and similar approaches demonstrate that intelligent query routing can achieve long-context performance while using only 38.6% of tokens [8]. Tiered systems that combine CAG's speed for core knowledge with RAG's flexibility for extended corpora represent a practical path forward for organizations with diverse query patterns.

For data scientists evaluating these approaches, the decision framework has clarified: assess knowledge base size, update frequency, and latency requirements. Knowledge bases under 100K tokens with infrequent updates are strong CAG candidates. Enterprise-scale deployments with dynamic knowledge require RAG. Most organizations will benefit from hybrid architectures that route queries to the appropriate system based on complexity and freshness requirements.

1. Introduction: Why Extensibility Matters in EHS Implementations

Implementing SAP Environment, Health & Safety (EHS) in the Public Cloud provides customers with a powerful set of standard capabilities across EHS functionality such as Incident Management, Risk Management, or Emissions Management. However, real-life EHS processes often include country-specific regulations, industry-dependent reporting obligations, and customer-individual workflows that cannot always be covered by the standard product alone. This is where extensibility becomes a critical success factor.

From our project experience, we see that nearly every EHS implementation requires selected adaptations ‚Äì whether to incorporate local legal requirements, enrich analytics, adjust incident forms, or create custom validations. With SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and SAP EHS, such enhancements must follow SAP‚Äôs clean-core principles, meaning they must be implemented using the officially supported extensibility technologies.

This blog post provides a clear, practical overview of the extensibility options available for SAP EHS in the Public Cloud and demonstrates how they can be applied to real-world scenarios.

1.1 What You Can Expect from This Blog Post

In this part, we outline the extensibility landscape for EHS Public Cloud and guide you through:

  • Which extensibility options exist in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • How they apply specifically to EHS use cases
  • Which BAdIs are available and when to use them
  • Concrete examples for extensibility
  • Best practices based on our project experience

The aim is to give implementation teams a practical understanding of how to adapt the system without breaking the clean core, ensuring long-term upgradeability and compliance.

1.2 Why Extensibility is Especially Important for EHS

From our project experience, EHS is one of the most extensibility-driven domains in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud because:

  • Regulations differ significantly by country (e.g. OSHA, EU directives, etc.)
  • Incident reports must reflect local legal requirements
  • Customers require tailored analytics and KPIs
  • Integration with external safety systems is common
  • Forms and regulatory outputs often need custom structures

EHS processes must adapt to organizational legal, and operational needs. Extensibility in Public Cloud ensures this adaptability without compromising SAP‚Äôs clean-core principles.

 

2. Extensibility Options in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provides a comprehensive extensibility portfolio designed to support innovation without compromising the stability of the core system. These capabilities range from low-code configuration tools for business users to pro-code development environments for technical teams. Understanding these options is essential for designing scalable, future-proof EHS solutions ‚Äì especially in Public Cloud environments where clean-core principles are mandatory.

Extensibility Portfolio for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

2.1 Low-Code vs. Pro-Code Extensibility

The extensibility portfolio is structured along two axes:

  • Low-Code: Target at key user and functional experts who need to quickly adapt user interfaces, create fields, or adjust logic without deep technical development.
  • Pro-Code: Designed for professional developers who require advanced capabilities through the ABAP Cloud development model or SAP BTP services.

These options are distributed across two major extensibility categories: On-Stack Extensibility (In-App) & Side-by-Side Extensibility.

2.2 On-Stack Extensibility (In-App)

Executed directly inside SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, following the clean-core principles enforced by SAP.

Key User & Developer Extensibility

2.2.1 Key User Extensibility (Low-Code)

Accessible directly via the SAP Fiori Launchpad, key user extensibility enables business focused adjustments such as:

  • UI adaptation mode: Modify screen layouts, hide/show fields, rearrange sections.
  • Custom fields: Create and publish custom fields that automatically extend UI, APIs, CDS views, and reports.
  • Custom logic (using BAdIs or BDEF extensions): Implement small logic enhancements using predefined extensions points.
  • Custom business objects: Model simple new business objects without coding.
  • Custom CDS views & OData services: Build analytical and integration-ready views with drag-and-drop tooling.
  • Analytical queries and applications: Extend reporting and KPIs in SAP Fiori or SAP Analytics Cloud.

Key User Extensibility is ideal for EHS teams that need to adapt processes quickly, e.g. adding a regulatory field in Incident Management or creating country-specific reporting structures.

2.2.2 Developer Extensibility (Pro-Code)

Developer Extensibility is performed using ABAP Cloud in Eclipse via ABAP Development Tools (ADT), enabling professional developers to build upgrade-safe extensions inside the SAP S/4HANA Cloud stack.

Typical capabilities include:

  • UI adaptation projects via SAP Business Application Studio
  • Extension fields built using professional ABAP development tools
  • Custom logic (BAdIs and BDEF extensions) with advanced editor capabilities
  • RAP Business Objects (full-fledge RESTful ABAP applications)
  • CDS views and OData services with full development tooling
  • Analytical queries and custom analytical content

This level of extensibility is used when EHS implementations require more complex data models, multi-step validations, or custom processes beyond the key user scope.

2.3 Side-by-Side Extensibility

When requirements cannot be fulfilled within the S/4HANA Cloud stack, SAP BTP provides a powerful platform for building complementary applications:

  • SAP Build Apps (no-code mobile and web apps)
  • SAP Build Process Automation (workflows and automations)
  • SAP Build Work Zone (custom dashboard and portals)
  • SAP Build Code / CAP (cloud-native pro-code development, Node.js/Java)
  • ABAP Environment on BTP (Steampunk) for ABAP Cloud side-by-side extensions

Side-by-side extensibility is particularly relevant for EHS when:

  • complex mobile solutions are required (e.g. hazard observations, audits)
  • workflow automation or robotic processing is desired
  • large-scale integration scenarios (e.g., IoT sensors, safety systems) are needed
  • custom employee or contractor portals must be built

Although side-by-side extensibility plays an important role in the overall SAP extensibility strategy, we will not dive deeper into BTP-based extensions in this blog post. Our objective is to demonstrate what can be achieved directly within the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, using standard in-app extensibility options that remain fully aligned with SAP‚Äôs clean-core principles. Based on our project experience, most EHS related enhancements such as custom fields, logic, reporting extensions, and form adaptations can be delivered efficiently using Key User or Developer Extensibility (on-stack). For this reason, the upcoming chapters focus exclusively on in-app, upgrade-safe extensibility scenarios that can be implemented without additional BTP architecture.

2.4 BAdIs in the Public Cloud (Key User vs. Developer Access)

Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) are predefined extension points provided by SAP that allow injecting custom logic while staying upgrade safe. You can explore the available BAdIs for the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud here: Business Add-Ins | SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) | SAP Business Accelerator Hub

There are two categories in S/4HANA Public Cloud:

Key User BAdIs

  • Implemented through the Custom Logic SAP Fiori app
  • Available only for selected business contexts
  • Designed for simple enhancements such as: Validation rules, Derivation of field values, Basic calculations

Developer BAdIs

  • Implemented using ABAP Development Tools (ADT) in SAP BTP ABAP Environment or Embedded Steampunk
  • Allow more complex coding scenarios
  • Enable interaction with APIs, CDS views, RAP BOs and advanced data handling

In EHS specifically, SAP provides a growing set of BAdIs ‚Äì particularly in Incident Management and Emissions Management ‚Äì which are essential for country specific reporting, custom form generation, or regulatory compliance.

The following list provides an overview of the EHS-specific BAdIs that are currently available in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Incident Management

  • BAdI: Change of Field Values in BG Incident Report (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Incident Basic Information (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Custom Field Incident Data (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Involved Person Data (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Incident Root Data (Key User)

Risk Management

  • (No BAdIs available for Risk Management in Public Cloud yet)

Emissions Management

  • BAdI: Field Control for Extension of Amount Root (Key User)
  • BAdI: Check Amounts State and Perform Subsequent Actions (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Generation of Export Files (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Compliance Requirement Import from XLSX (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Automatic Data Collection Import (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Automatic Data Collection Import from XLSX BAdI (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Automatic Data Collection XLSX Parser BAdI (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Field Control for Extension of Data Collection Root (Key User)

As the overview shows, the currently available BAdIs for EHS in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud are primarily focused on Key User Extensibility, especially within Incident Management and Emissions Management. While Developer Extensibility via ABAP Cloud provides a more advanced pro-code extension model, the current EHS-specific enhancement points are mostly delivered as in-app, low-code BAdIs to ensure upgrade stability and full alignment with SAP‚Äôs clean core principles.

This corresponds closely with our experience from project implementations: Most EHS extension requirements can be delivered efficiently using in-app, Key User Extensibility tools such as Custom Fields, Custom Logic, UI Adaptation, and CDS View extensions without requiring developer access.

 

3. Practical Extensibility Scenarios in EHS

In chapter 2, we explored the extensibility options available in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and outlined which of these options are most relevant for EHS implementations. As highlighted, the majority of extensibility points currently exposed in the EHS area (especially within Incident Management and Emissions Management) are implemented using Key User Extensibility, including custom fields, UI adaptation, form template configuration, and Custom Logic BAdIs.

Because of this, this chapter focuses exclusively on Key User Extensibility in practice, demonstrating how customers can solve real-world EHS requirements entirely within the Public Cloud without requiring developer extensibility or SAP BTP side-by-side extensions.

Drawing from our project experience, we selected two scenarios that reflect common customer requirements:

  1. Adding custom attributes to the Incident Management process
  2. Generating a country-specific incident report, using custom form templates and multiple BAdIs

Both scenarios illustrate how far customers can go using the extensibility tools embedded in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, while fully adhering to the clean-core principle.

3.1 Example 1 - Introducing a Custom Attribute for Incident Records

Extensibility Type:

  • Key User Extensibility

Tools & Apps Used:

  • Custom Fields App (SAP Fiori App)
  • UI Adaptation (SAP Fiori Settings)

3.1.1 Business Requirement

Many organizations require an additional field ‚ÄúBusiness Unit‚Äù to be captured as part of incident documentation to meet internal reporting needs, support organizational analysis, or fulfill local compliance requirements. Since this information is not available in the standard SAP EHS Public Cloud data model, customers often need to introduce it as a custom field.

Typically, the Business Unit may be required in multiple stages of the Incident Management process, such as:

  • Incident Creation
  • Incident Processing
  • Reporting and Analytics Dashboards

In our case, the Business Unit field was only added to the Incident Processing step, primarily for simplicity and to demonstrate the extensibility approach in clear and focused manner. However, this field can be added to additional UIs and process steps as needed, depending on the customer‚Äôs specific requirements, organizational structure, or compliance obligations.

3.1.2 Step-by-Step Implementation

Create New Custom Field

In this step a custom field for the Incident Management will be created using the ‚ÄúCustom Fields‚Äù Fiori App. You can follow the steps below to create a custom field:

1. Navigate to the ‚ÄúCustom Fields‚Äù app from the Fiori Launchpad.

2. Click ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù.

3. Enter the following details:

  • Business Context: Select the relevant context (e.g. EHHSS_INC_BINFA).
  • Label: Provide a meaningful name (Business Unit). Identifier & Tooltip will be filled automatically.
  • Type: Choose from options like Text, Number, Date, etc.
  • Length: Define the size of the field if applicable.

Create New Field

After the required details have been filled, select Create and Edit.

4. Enable the fields for the relevant applications.

The fields of the tabs User Interfaces, Analytics and APIs will be enabled by default. These tabs are required to support user interactions, reporting as well as integrations for the recently added custom field (Business Unit).

Field Enablement

If the new field should appear in generated documents such as PDFs or reports, you need to enable the required Form Templates. In our scenario, two Form Templates were activated as shown below.

Enabled Form Templates

Note: The YY1_WHS_FORM10 Template is a custom Form Template. The creation of this Form Template will be shown in chapter 3.2.

5. Save and publish the custom field to make it available in the system.

 

Assign custom field to Fiori app

Custom fields created by using the ‚ÄúCustom Fields‚Äù Fiori app can be assigned to the relevant Fiori applications based on the selected business context. Follow these steps to add the field:

1. Open the ‚ÄúManage Incident‚Äù Fiori app & click on any incident.

2. Click on your profile & choose ‚ÄúAdapt UI‚Äù

Navigate to "Adapt UI"

 3. Once Adapt UI is activated, you can start customizing the page layout and add the recently created custom field to the relevant sections. By selecting ‚ÄúCustomize‚Äù > ‚ÄúShow Customizable Areas‚Äù as shown below, you will be able to insert the new custom field ‚ÄúBusiness Unit‚Äù into the desired section of the Fiori App.

Navigate to "Show Customizable Areas"

 4. Select the Customizable Area that should be changed.

Select Customizable Area

 5. Select the element as shown below & click on ‚ÄúCustomize UIBB‚Äù.

Select "Customize UIBB"

 6. To add the new field, select ‚ÄúElement‚Äù > ‚ÄúAdd Element‚Äù.

Add Element

 7. Select the recently created field YY1_BUSINESSUNIT_IBN and select ‚ÄúOK‚Äù.

Select field YY1_BUSINESSUNIT_IBN

 

In the below shown illustration you can see an example, after the Business Unit was added to the UI.

Field Business Unit added to UI

 8. Save the UI adaptation for this page.  

 

3.2 Example 2 - Generating a Country-Specific Incident Report

Extensibility Type:

  • Key User Extensibility

Tools & Apps Used:

  • Adobe Lifecycle Designer (External Tool)
  • Maintain Form Template App (SAP Fiori App)
  • Custom Logic App (SAP Fiori App)
  • CBC Configuration (SAP Public Cloud) / or if no access exists Implementation Activities (SAP Fiori App)

3.2.1 Business Requirement

In many EHS implementations, customers need to generate country-specific incident reports that comply with national legal requirements. These reports often require a combination of standard fields, people related information, and custom fields that are not provided in the SAP EHS Public Cloud standard forms. For example, organizations operating in Australia may be required to submit the WHS Form 10, a mandatory workplace health and safety report documenting incidents, injuries, or hazards in accordance with the Australian Work Health and Safety (WHS) Regulations (made-up). To support this requirement, a custom Adobe form template must be created and populated with incident data, including custom fields. This requires implementing the relevant Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) to retrieve, map, and supply the correct incident information into the custom form.

The report must include:

  • Basic incident details
  • Person and involvement information
  • Custom fields required for the local legislative format

3.2.2 Step-by-Step Implementation

Develop a Custom Form in Adobe Lifecycle Designer

A custom form template needs to be created to meet the specific requirements of the report. The form should include all necessary fields. To showcase this example, we created the form template YY1_WHS_FORM10 in Adobe Lifecycle Designer and saved it as an xdp file.

Form Template Creation in Adobe Lifecycle Designer

 

Upload Custom Form in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

Once the custom form template is created in Adobe Lifecycle Designer, the next step is to upload it to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud by using the ‚ÄúMaintain Form Template‚Äù app.

1. Open the ‚ÄúMaintain Form Template‚Äù app in your SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system.

2. Navigate to the ‚ÄúCustom Template‚Äù tab.

3. Click ‚ÄúNew‚Äù to create a new entry.

4. Enter a Form Template Name of your choice (for example ‚ÄúYY1_WHS_FORM10‚Äù including the prefix ‚ÄúYY1_‚Äù for custom forms).

5. Upload the form file that you created in Adobe Lifecycle Designer.

6. Select the Data Source Name as ‚ÄúEHSS_FDP_INCIDENT_SRV‚Äù.

The illustration below shows how the form setup was done in our scenario.

Form Setup (1)

Form Setup (2)

 

Assign Custom Fields & Custom Logic to the form

In this step we assign the created custom fields & logic to the form (shown in the previous step). This is achieved by using the ‚ÄúCustom Logic‚Äù app in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, where you can leverage the available Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) provided by the system. To retrieve the required information in the form, you can implement the following BAdIs:

  • BADI_EHHSS_INC_BASIC_INFO
  • BADI_EHHSS_INC_INVOLVED_PERS
  • BADI_EHHSS_INC_ROOT

1. Click ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù to start a new implementation.

2. Select one of the mentioned BAdIs above and proceed to ‚ÄúStep 2‚Äù (if no filters are needed jump over to step 3 and enter an Implementation Description).

3. Create and publish the Implementation.

4. Navigate to the created Implementation.

Created Implementations

 5. Select ‚ÄúCode Editor‚Äù and write ABAP logic using released APIs and CDS views.

Open Code Editor

The below shown BAdI implementation YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_BASIC_INFO retrieves incident basic information from the CDS View I_IncidentBasicInfo and populates the INCIDENTBASICINFO structure, so that key fields such as the Creation Date Time or Business Unit (which was previously created as a custom field in chapter 3.1) are available in the custom form.

YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_BASIC_INFO

Perform the same steps for the other required BadIs.

BAdI YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_INVOLVED_PE retrieves involved person details, such as Person‚Äôs Full Name, from the CDS View I_IncidentInvolvedPerson which makes it available in the custom form.

YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_INVOLVED_PE

BAdI YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_ROOT retrieves root-level incident data such as CreationDateTime from the CDS View I_Incident and makes these fields available for the custom form.

YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_ROOT

Note: BAdIs are essential because they supply data for custom and standard fields in the form. Without these implementations, the fields would remain empty, as the standard logic does not retrieve the required CDS view information.

6. Click ‚ÄúPublish‚Äù to implement.

 

Functional Configuration (Assign Form to regulation)

Uploading the Adobe form just makes the template available in the system. To actually use it in the EHS process, you need to specify the form and assign it to the correct form group and regulation. This ensures the form is linked to the appropriate compliance context and can be selected when generating reports.

This can be achieved by performing the mentioned steps below performed in the SAP Central Business Configuration (or ‚ÄùImplementation Activities‚Äù app).

1. Specify form: Select one of the mentioned apps above and navigate to SAP Business Configuration > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety > Specify Forms

Each form entry shows key technical attributes:

  • Form Name & Form Title : Represents the form to be specified (In our scenario: WHS).
  • Form Type: Indicates the technology used for the form. In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, this is typically ‚ÄúSAP Interactive Form‚Äù, which refers to Adobe-based forms used for output and reporting.
  • Form Controller: Controls the rendering and behavior of the form in SAP (In our scenario: CL_EHFND_FW_ADS_OM_FORM_CTRL).
  • Data Provider: Supplies the data from the EHS process to the form (In our scenario: CL_EHHSS_AIF_INCIDENT_DPROV).
  • Form Object Name: Identifies the form template used for output. This should match the custom form you uploaded earlier in the ‚ÄúMaintain Form Template‚Äù app (In our scenario: YY1_WHS_FORM10).

Specify Form

 2. Assign Form to the Form Group: Select one of the mentioned apps above and navigate to SAP Business Configuration  > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety > Specify Form Groups and Assign Forms

Assign Form to Form Group (1)

After defining the form groups, the next step is to assign the relevant specified forms to these groups. This can be performed on the second level of the selected form group and ensures that the custom or standard forms are correctly linked to the appropriate reporting or regulatory context.

Assign Form to Form Group (2)

 3. Specify Regulations & assign Regulation to Incidents: Select one of the mentioned apps above and navigate to SAP Business Configuration > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety >  Specify Regulations.

Specify Regulations & Assign Regulation to Incidents (1)

After specifying the regulation (e.g., WHS), the next step is to assign it to the relevant incident categories. This ensures that when users select a regulation in the Incident process, the correct forms from the assigned form group become available for reporting.

Specify Regulations & Assign Regulation to Incidents (2)

 4. Assign the Forms to Regulations: Finally, link the forms to the corresponding regulation. This step ensures that when a regulation (e.g., WHS) is selected in the Incident process, the correct form becomes available for reporting.

Therefore, open the SAP Central Business Configuration > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety > Assign Forms to Regulations.

Assign Forms to Regulations

 

Generating the Report

Once the configuration is complete, you can generate the report directly from the ‚ÄúManage Incident‚Äù app.

1. Open the ‚ÄúManage Incident‚Äù app

2. Select any Incident which has the status  ‚ÄúIn Process‚Äù.

3. Click on ‚ÄúRegulations‚Äù, choose ‚ÄúWHS‚Äù, then click ‚ÄúOK‚Äù and‚Äù Save‚Äù.

Generate Report (1)

After selecting the WHS regulation, the system makes the corresponding report option available under the ‚ÄúReports‚Äù tab.

4. Navigate to the ‚ÄúReports‚Äù tab.

5. Select the WHS Report from the list.

6. Click ‚ÄúGenerate‚Äù to create the report.

Generate Report (2)

Once you click ‚ÄúGenerate‚Äù for the selected Report Type, the WHS report is created and appears in the list as a downloadable PDF.

Generate Report (3)

The final output reflects all required incident details, including custom and standard fields, in the WHS Form 10 format.

Output

 

4. Summary & Lessons Learned

Extensibility plays a critical role in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud implementations for Environment, Health, and Safety (EHS). As demonstrated throughout this blog post, even highly regulated processes such as incident reporting or country-specific compliance documentation can be effectively supported using SAP‚Äôs clean-core extensibility framework.

Drawing from our project experience and the two practical use cases presented, this chapter summarizes the key takeaways and highlights the most important lessons learned when implementing extensibility in EHS Public Cloud.

4.1 Key Takeaways

Clean-Core Extensibility Is Not a Limitation ‚Äì It is a Design Principle

The SAP Public Cloud model enforces strict boundaries around what can be extended. Rather than restricting customers, these boundaries ensure:

  • Long-term upgrade protection
  • Predictable lifecycle behavior
  • Lower maintenance effort
  • Full SAP supportability

All enhancements must therefore rely on SAP-released extension points.

Most EHS Requirements Can Be Solved with Key User Extensibility

A major insight from our implementations is that the majority of EHS use cases do not require developer extensibility or side-by-side applications.

Key User tools already cover:

  • Custom data fields
  • UI adaptations
  • PDF report adjustments
  • BAdI logic

Both examples in this blog were fully implemented using Key User Extensibility only.

BAdIs Are the Backbone of EHS Extensibility

SAP delivers a growing catalogue of EHS specific BAdIs in the Public Cloud, particularly for:

  • Incident Management
  • Emissions Management

Key lessons:

  • Each BAdI is designed for a very specific business context.
  • You often need to use several BAdIs together to populate a report for a form.
  • They enable retrieving structured data via released CDS Views and APIs.
  • Clean and modular implementations significantly improve maintainability.

Custom Forms Require a Structured Approach

Regulatory reports require a combination of:

  • A form template (Adobe)
  • Custom fields
  • BAdI logic
  • CBC configuration

The lesson: Form extensibility is not only a technical activity ‚Äì it is a cross-functional exercise involving business, logic, and configuration layers.

Configuration in SAP Central Business Configuration (CBC) / Implementation Activities is Essential

EHS reporting relies heavily on CBC / Implementation Activities, especially when assigning:

  • Forms > form groups
  • Form groups > regulations
  • Regulations > incident categories

A common project challenge: Without correct CBC (or Implementation Activities) configuration, even perfectly implemented forms and BAdIs will not appear in the UI.

End-to-End Testing Is Crucial

Because EHS extensions span UI, logic, reporting and configuration layers, testing must always validate the entire lifecycle:

  • Incident creation > processing > regulation selection > report generation

This avoids fragmented testing and ensures that all extension layers work together seamlessly.

4.2 Lessons Learned

Start With the Simplest Possible Extension Option

Always begin with Key User tools before considering Developer Extensibility or SAP BTP. Public Cloud projects succeed when complexity is added only where absolutely necessary.

Choose BAdIs Wisely ‚Äì Don‚Äôt Over-Engineer

Each BAdI serves a narrow purpose. Trying to force a single BAdI to solve multiple needs often causes issues later. Modular, purpose-aligned implementations are easier to maintain and debug.

Document Custom Logic and Configuration Thoroughly

Because Public Cloud enforces strict structure, even small enhancements should be:

  • Named consistently (YY1_*)
  • Documented cleanly (purpose, input, output)
  • Readable for team members who join the project later.

Well-documented extensions also reduce future rework during audits or regulatory updates.

Maintain a Strong Governance Around Extensibility

Typical governance measures include:

  • Reviewing whether a need truly requires an extension
  • Maintaining a central register of custom fields and BAdIs
  • Ensuring no duplicate fields are created
  • Enforcing naming conventions

This prevents uncontrolled growth of extensions over time.

Engage Business Users Early in the Design Process

EHS professionals often know exactly how regulations should be represented. Early involvement helps:

  • Avoid unnecessary extensions
  • Validate report layouts
  • Confirm the accuracy of populated data
  • Ensure usability in real operational scenarios

Plan for Future Regulatory Requirements

EHS compliance evolves frequently. When building extensions, always think ahead:

  • Could this field or form be reused for another regulation?
  • Can we structure the logic to accommodate more categories in the future?
  • Are we using modular BAdI implementations that can scale?

This significantly reduces technical dept.

4.3 Best Practices

To close this chapter, here is a consolidated best-practice checklist:

  • Use SAP-released extension points only (clean core).
  • Prefer Key User Extensibility for EHS whenever possible.
  • Keep BAdI implementations modular and business-context specific.
  • Use functional naming conventions for fields, forms, and BAdIs.
  • Perform end-to-end lifecycle testing (UI > logic > form > CBC).
  • Document every extension early, including purpose and data sources.
  • Reuse released CDS Views and APIs ‚Äì never rely on unreleased objects.
  • Involve business users early to ensure regulatory accuracy.
  • Build form templates in a future-proof, scalable structure.
  • Maintain strong governance to avoid unnecessary or duplicate extensions.

4.4 Final Remark

Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is not about pushing technical boundaries. It is about using the right tools to deliver business value while protecting system integrity. With a structured approach, as illustrated in both examples, customers can achieve regulatory compliance, process optimization, and system flexibility without compromising the clean-core principles that define the Public Cloud.

 

 

5. Engage with Us

entry.title: The Hidden Behavior of LLMs - Prompt Caching and Determinism
entry.content:
The Hidden Behavior of LLMs - The LLM Prompt Caching and Determinism
Are LLMs Really Stateless?

A Developer‚Äôs Deep Dive Into the Hidden Behavior of LLMs (with code-gen as the use case)

Introduction: The "Wait, What?" Moment

I recently started building a code generation tool using Large Language Models (LLMs) via API calls. Like many of you, I learned the golden rule of LLM development early on: LLMs are stateless. They don‚Äôt "remember" past requests; every API call is a fresh start.

But as I tested my tool, I noticed something that confused me.

  1. Whenever I made changes in my prompt instructions: The output was perfect!
  2. When I changed nothing and sent the exact same request: The output still changed!

I expected that if the inputs were identical (and the model is stateless), the result should be consistent. This inconsistency led me down a rabbit hole of research where I landed on a feature that completely changed how I optimize my workflows: Prompt Caching.

If you are building AI Agents or Code Gen tools on SAP BTP (using SAP Generative AI Hub) or directly via provider APIs, this is a mechanism you need to understand‚Äînot just for speed, but to clear up the "caching" misconception.

The Myth Buster: "Prompt Cache" NE "Response Cache"

Here is the inference I made during my research, which might clear up your confusion too:

The Reality: Prompt Caching does not cache the answer. It caches the question.

When we hear "Cache" in software development (like SAP ABAP or SAP HANA), we think of storing the result to serve it instantly next time. Prompt Caching is different. It caches the pre-computation of your input context (the Key-Value states of the attention mechanism). It essentially "pre-loads" the model's brain with your long documents, codebases, or instructions.

However, the generation of the response is still calculated fresh, token by token. This brings us to the second major realization‚Äîwhy your output changes even when the prompt doesn't.

The "Temperature=0" Trap: Why It‚Äôs Still Not Deterministic

You might think, "If the prompt is cached and I set Temperature to 0, shouldn't the output be identical every time?"

The short answer: No.

The technical answer: Modern LLMs are only "mostly" deterministic, even at Temperature=0.

While setting the temperature to 0 forces greedy decoding (always picking the highest-probability next token), real-world infrastructure introduces subtle variations:

  1. Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) Architecture: Models like GPT-4 are believed to use a "Sparse MoE" design. Different "expert" subnetworks handle different parts of your input. Parallel routing and slight gating differences can introduce non-determinism in the path your data takes.
  2. GPU "Fuzziness": Modern GPUs perform massive parallel operations. Because floating-point arithmetic is non-associative, the order of operations can shift slightly based on thread scheduling. A microscopic rounding error can flip a token choice when two words have nearly identical probabilities.
  3. System Variance: Your request might hit a different backend instance or hardware generation (indicated by the system_fingerprint in OpenAI responses).

The Takeaway: Even with a cached prompt and zero temperature, expect minor "drift" in your outputs. The prompt cache speeds up the input processing, but the output generation remains subject to the complex physics of AI hardware.

How It Works: Implicit vs. Explicit

Different vendors handle this differently. If you are using models via SAP Generative AI Hub, it's crucial to know how the underlying models behave.

Implicit Caching (The "It Just Works" Approach)

Vendors: OpenAI (GPT-4.1), Google (Gemini)

  • Mechanism: You don't need to change your code. If the API detects that the first 1,024+ tokens of your prompt match a previous request sent recently, it automatically uses the cached processing.
  • Pros: Zero developer effort.
  • Cons: Less control over what stays in the cache.

Explicit Caching (The "Precision" Approach)

Vendor: Anthropic (Claude 3.5 and > Sonnet/Haiku)

  • Mechanism: You must explicitly tell the API where to stop caching. You insert a cache_control parameter at a specific "checkpoint" in your message history.
  • Pros: You guarantee that your heavy context (like a full ABAP codebase or API specification) is cached.
  • Cons: Requires a small code change.

A Common Practice for Agentic AI & Code Gen

In my code generation use case, I send the entire project context (libraries, style guides, and current code) with every request. Without caching, this is slow and expensive.

The Strategy:

Organize your prompt so the static content is at the top.

  1. System Prompt (Static: "You are an ABAP Expert...")
  2. Context/Documentation (Static: "Here is the SAP Cloud SDK documentation...") -> [CACHE CHECKPOINT]
  3. User Query (Dynamic: "Write a method to fetch Business Partners.")

By placing the checkpoint after the documentation, the model "reads" the docs once. For every subsequent user query, it skips the heavy lifting and jumps straight to generating code.

Verifying the Speed Up: Analyze Your Logs

How do you know it's working? You won't see "same output," but you will see "faster time-to-first-token."

Look at the usage metadata in your API response.

  • OpenAI: Look for cached_tokens in the usage object.
  • Anthropic: Look for cache_read_input_tokens.
  • Google Gemini: Look for cachedContentTokenCount.

Example Analysis:

  • Request 1 (Cold): Input Tokens: 10,000 | Processing Time: 4.5s
  • Request 2 (Warm): Input Tokens: 10,000 (9,900 Cached!) | Processing Time: 0.8s

Why could this be a game-changer?

  • Latency: The model doesn't have to "read" your 5,000-line code file every time. It "remembers" the reading process.
  • Cost: You pay significantly less (often ~90% less) for the cached tokens.

If you see the processing time drop drastically while the output remains high-quality (and slightly varied), you have successfully implemented Prompt Caching.

My Personal Inference: The "Bad Roll" & The Butterfly Effect

During my testing, I encountered a frustrating scenario that I believe many developers will face.

  • The Scenario: I used OpenAI for code generation. When the prompt was cached (no changes), the code quality was consistently "not perfect"‚Äîit had minor bugs or incomplete logic.
  • The Fix: When I added just one single word to the prompt, the code generation suddenly became perfect.
  • The Contrast: Switching to Anthropic (without caching) gave me complete code every time.

Why did adding one word fix the OpenAI output? This is what I call the "Deterministic Trap." When you use a cached prompt with a low temperature (which we usually do for code), the model is mathematically locked into a specific "reasoning path." If the model generates a suboptimal solution (a "bad roll") on the first try, the cached state ensures it starts from the exact same mathematical position next time. It essentially "remembers" the path to the bad answer.

By adding a single word, I forced a "Cache Miss" (or at least a perturbation in the attention mechanism). This acted like the "Butterfly Effect"‚Äîit shifted the token probabilities just enough to force the model to calculate a fresh path, allowing it to escape the "bad roll" and find the correct solution.

The Lesson: Prompt Caching is powerful for speed, but if you notice your model is "stuck" giving you the same bad code repeatedly, don't just retry. Change the prompt. Even a single extra adjective can shake the model out of a local minimum and produce the perfect result.

Conclusion

LLMs are stateless, but Prompt Caching gives them a "short-term memory" for processing inputs. While it won't force your outputs to be bit-for-bit identical (due to MoE and GPU nuances), it will make your applications significantly faster and cheaper to run.

Next Step: Check your current API logs. If you are sending long contexts (>1024 tokens) repeatedly, you might already be benefiting from implicit caching, or you may need to add cache_control headers for Anthropic models to unlock these savings.

References & Further Reading

  • Anthropic Prompt Caching: (https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/build-with-claude/prompt-caching)
  • OpenAI Prompt Caching: (https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/prompt-caching)
  • Google Gemini Context Caching: (https://ai.google.dev/gemini-api/docs/caching)
  • SAP Generative AI Hub: (https://help.sap.com/docs/sap-ai-core/generative-ai-hub)

Hi Yaya_AB,

In general, acquisition costs on an asset are always positive and depreciation is negative. In some GAAP these rules are mandatory, in some others more flexibility is allowed. Let me provide one typical example:

  • You post an logistics invoice to asset and capitalize the asset
  • But then you need to revers the invoice. But from bookkeeping perspective this is no reversal but a credit-memo postings. 
  • Due to currently translation the asset will receive a higher APC correction in at least one currency, resulting violation of the sign rule of APC.

This give you two choice: either you allow negative values on this asset until the next (correct) acquisition is posted via new invoice or you manually post the missing difference to the asset to avoid the sign rule violation. Which option is best, depends on your internal processes and legal compliance to the GAAP you use. In case of doubt, align with your financial auditor. We clearly DO NOIT recommend to allow negative values for all ordinary assets.

BR; MICK

entry.title: Expose BW 7.5 objects as Data products in Databricks
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs data-driven organizations, turning enterprise data into shareable, consumable products is critical. With the introduction of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC)  SAP plans to expand and explore this area, and help customer to achieve it with reducing the data footprints. This blog walks through a practical, end-to-end process for creating a Data Product from SAP BW and exposing it securely to Databricks using SAP DSP (Data Sphere/Platform) and the BDC Cockpit.

In this article we would expose SAP BW 7.5 artefacts as custom into SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) and the expose the data products to an SAP Databricks environment for consumptiom.

Prerequisites

The Data Product Generator for SAP Business Data Cloud is available for the releases SAP BW/4HANA 2023 SP0 or higher, SAP BW/4HANA 2021 SP4 or higher, and SAP BW on SAP NetWeaver 7.50 SP24 or higher.For the configuration of the Data Product Generator for SAP Business Data Cloud, see SAP Note 3590400

 
The DW Administrator should create at least one of the following types of scoped roles and assign users to them:

  • DW Space Administrator: to manage users and do monitoring

  • DW Integrator: to monitor data integration in the space

  • DW Modeler: to share the tables to other spaces for consumption

You should have access to Databricks environment.

Creating Data Products from SAP BW System

Step 1: Logon to your SAP BW 7.5 

Start by connecting to the BW system using SAP Logon. The environment should be preconfigured to work with SAP BDC, and access credentials are typically shared by an administrator.

Step 2: Create BW Subscription

To create BW subscription to SAP BDC object store

 

  • Launch  the transaction RSDPS.

  • Choose Create and select the relevant InfoProvider (InfoCubes, DSOs, ADSOs etc.) as the source.

  • Select the Extraction Mode, the option available are "Full", "Delta" and "Streaming".
  • The Target is automatically selected "Datasphere Local Table".
  • Save the subscription with a clear description, as it is mandatory step.
 

 

  • Activate it using Activate Subscription. Once the subscription is "Active" run the subscription to generate a local table in DSP

Once active, this subscription creates the underlying data structure that DSP will use.

 

Step 3: Validate the Data Products (Tables) in SAP BDC Datasphere

Connect to SAP BDC Datasphere and open Data Builder on object store space to see the newly created table by the subscription, the table name should match the ‚Äúdescription‚Äù entered in the subscription.

Deploy the table and preview the data to ensure everything looks correct.

The source from BW system is exposed as tables in the object store ( HANA Data Lake ) space in SAP BDC Datasphere, now to share these tables to Databricks.

 

Step 4: Create a Data Provider Profile in SAP BDC Datasphere

Before creating Data Products, you must set up a Data Provider Profile:

In SAP BDC Datasphere navigate to Data Sharing Cockpit ‚Üí My Data Provider Profile, and Create Data Provider Profile.

Fill in required fields, enable Formations, and complete the namespace, provide an email id and save the data profile.
 

Step 5: Build Your Data Product

  • In SAP Datasphere select ‚ÄúData Sharing Cockpit‚Äù -> ‚ÄúMy Data Products‚Äù and select the blue + sign  to create a new ‚ÄúData Product‚Äù.
  • Make sure you select the correct space as "Artifact Space", complete the required fields.

 

  • Go down in the product creation page until Product Artefacts, Add an Artefact and select the local table created in previous Step
  • Save the Data Product
  • Go to Switch Status and select ‚ÄúList‚Äù to make the data Product available in the BDC cockpit.

 

Step 5: Share the Data Product with Databricks

To make your Data Product available to Databricks follow the steps below

  • Open the BDC Cockpit.

  • Search for your Data Product in Catalog & Marketplace.

 

 
  • Select the Data Product and click on the share button as shown below.
  • Select the appropriate target in the list, here we select the DBX server associated to this environment. If it is not listed just click ‚ÄúAdd Target‚Äù and select it from the list

 

  • Once Data Product is successfully shared, you can open it in Databricks using the Open icon in the sharing panel (in red above)
  • Databricks login page opens, use your email and ‚Äúcontinue with SSO‚Äù, as we are using SAP Databricks landscape.
  • Databricks opens and displays the catalog objects created for the Data Product.

The above steps  creates a secure, governed data sharing channel with no manual file exports or insecure data copies, reducing Data Footprints accross landscape.

 

 

 

Summary

This process transforms raw BW data into a governed, shareable Data Product that business and engineering teams can immediately use in Databricks. With proper subscriptions, profiles, and sharing, you can create a seamless data pipeline from SAP to modern analytics platforms. 

This end-to-end flow demonstrates how organizations can:

‚úÖ Govern enterprise data
‚úÖ Package it as reusable products
‚úÖ Share it securely across platforms
‚úÖ Enable faster analytics and innovation

Instead of copying data between systems, this approach builds a single, trusted pipeline from SAP BW to SAP BDC to Databricks.

entry.title: Re: KONV-KKURS exchange rate overwrite
entry.content:
Hi Yesh,
If you implement custom logic in a user exit to overwrite KONV-KKURS with your own conversion rate the Pricing Consistency, Condition values may no longer match the original order or delivery pricing. This can lead to discrepancies between FI postings and SD documents.

Accounting Integration
The exchange rate is critical for revenue postings to FI/CO. Overwriting it may cause mismatches between SD billing and FI accounting documents.

Tax Calculations
If taxes are condition-based, changing the rate can alter tax amounts unexpectedly.

Reconciliation Issues
Reports comparing SD and FI (e.g., CO-PA, revenue recognition) may show differences if exchange rates are inconsistent.

Audit/Compliance
Exchange rates are often subject to audit requirements. Custom overrides could raise compliance concerns if not properly documented.

My advice to your, instead of directly overwriting KONV-KKURS. Use standard exchange rate determination (OB08, currency type settings). If business requires a special rate (e.g., fixed contract rate), consider. Creating a custom condition type for exchange rate handling. Using pricing routines (VOFM) rather than hard overwriting KONV fields. Storing the custom rate in a Z-field for reporting, while keeping KONV consistent.

entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies Series: singing, acting, advocating and... supporting
entry.content:
Who I am 

My name is Marika Porto, and I work as a Technical Lead Consultant at Mindset, an italian SAP Silver Partner company.
Special thanks to @JanRumig for passing the word on to me - and @smarchesini for pushing me, every day, to get out of my comfort zone a little more üòâ 
Today, I‚Äôd like to share a bit about my hobbies, joining the amazing  SAP Community Hobbies series. 
I have quite a few of them, and I hope some of you might share at least one with me! 
My hobbies play an important role in my life because they help me clear my mind and think more effectively, especially when I face challenging situations at work.
 

Why I decide to sing so awfully that even the clouds start crying

One of my favorite hobbies is singing! About a year ago, I started taking weekly singing lessons with a teacher, and it‚Äôs honestly one of the best things I‚Äôve done for myself lately. Singing has given me a ton of satisfaction‚Äîespecially because I‚Äôve had the courage to perform in front of bigger crowds (over a hundred people!), a song in Sicilian language. 
 
For me, singing is a way to truly connect with myself and focus only on the feelings in my body, which is something I hardly get to do in my daily work life. Paying attention to my tone, volume, and how I position my mouth and lips forces me to be mindful and listen to what‚Äôs going on inside me. Sometimes it hurts, but this self-awareness is such a bonus, both personally and even at work‚Äîit‚Äôs a great stress reliever and confidence booster! Plus, I like to think I‚Äôm not too bad at it: my husband hasn‚Äôt asked for a divorce yet, so I must be on the right track! üòÅ

 
This photo from my latest concert. in July 2025. I sang 'La Fine' - a song write by Francesco Tarducci (aka Nesli).
This song was hard to sing due to its introspective way: 'Arriver√† la fine, ma non sar√† la fine" - It will be the end... but I will never be
 

The best way to learn empathy: acting

My second big passion is acting!
I spend about four hours a week with a local theater group in my city called Lampioni Storti‚Äîthey're super welcoming, even though I have a strong Southern Italian accent and they're all Northerners.
They've let me dive into everything behind the scenes: the training, prep, and all the hard work that goes into staging a comedy. So my gap become something really special, at the end.
 
Acting is huge for me because it teaches real empathy‚Äîyou have to fully step into someone else's shoes and live their story. And since we do comedies, nothing beats hearing the audience laugh; it's pure magic!
 
Next year, I'll even get my shot at a proper acting role, which I'm thrilled about.
 
It was a lot of fun, on March 2025, being the most annoying girlfriend possible in a play.
The audience identified so much that at a certain point they actually started hating me!
But I have to say, I'm pretty good as a blonde... 
 

M71A for women's equality in tech

My third hobby‚Äîand the one I'm most proud of‚Äîis being an activist for M71A, the Italian Manifesto for Equality of Girls and Women in Technology. It's a volunteer-driven group focused on gender equality in tech, tackling the gender gap and the challenges women face breaking through in our industry. Our big goal is cultural awareness to push for real change.
 
I got involved because I want to do my part, especially in the SAP world where I work daily. It's inspiring to fight for a more inclusive tech space where talent shines regardless of gender. 
 
I‚Äôd love to be a role model for someone‚Äîespecially a female role model in tech‚Äîjust like the incredible women who inspired me during my career to dive into technology and SAP. Seeing strong female leaders made all the difference, pushing me to pursue this path despite the challenges. Now, through my activism, I hope to pay it forward and encourage the next generation of women in our field to break barriers and thrive.
 
That's the badge that you can share if you sign the Manifesto. A way to be proud to be part of a important wind of change.

Being a sports supporter = pursuing a common goal together

My fourth hobby‚Äîand probably the most fun of all‚Äîis being a die-hard volleyball fan! From October through March or April, I join the organized supporters group, named "Men In Black Group", for Pallavolo Padova, one of Italy's top SuperLega teams (the premier men's league). Sundays mean chanting new cheers, losing my voice, and dealing with Monday morning throat pain, all while surrounded by a huge crowd with different vibes but the same fiery passion.
 
It's chaos in the best way‚Äîcoordinating with fans who all want different things but pull together for one goal. Being in that energy reminds me how powerful it is to spot a shared objective and row in the same direction, a lesson that translates straight to teamwork at work. 
Being a supporter doesn't mean to join a violent group of people: it's just the opposite. You are in the right place with people that respect the opposite players. No scream, no shout, only positives happy vibes!
And when your favorite team loses, we all think about next time, because there's always a next time.
If you persist and persevere, you'll achieve and conquer!
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
A happy me beating the drum to support the team.
About two hours of play where the only thought is pushing the boys to never give up, as a leader must do everyday!

How to get started and how to achieve your first goals with these hobbies

To get started as a beginner in any of these hobbies, the key essentials aren't gear or fancy resources‚Äîthey're curiosity to dive in and the courage to put yourself out there, facing some of your biggest fears head-on.
 
Things like public speaking, expressing raw emotions, or sharing what you truly care about can feel scary at first, but pushing through builds real confidence that spills over into work and life. Start small, practice with people you trust, and breathe deeply to stay grounded‚Äîit's all about that first step of getting uncomfortable to grow.
 
Any actor, singer, activist, supporter out there?
Let's chat!
 
Love from Marika

entry.title: SAP Translation Hub rolls out term-aware post-editing of AI translated content
entry.content:
Machine translation is a practical tool for organizations managing software localization at scale. However, a common challenge is that standard translation engines tend to produce generic output that doesn‚Äôt account for terminology that is specific to an organization, a brand or an industry. This means that product names, unique UI labels, and industry-specific terms often require manual correction after the initial translation, creating additional work in the post-editing phase.

To address this workflow challenge, SAP Translation Hub now offers term-aware translation as part of our Intelligent Data Reuse component. This capability is designed to incorporate your custom glossaries directly into the AI translation process, both with SAP neural machine translation as well as with our LLM-based translation provider.

 

How term-aware translation works

The feature operates through a straightforward mechanism:

  • Define Your terminology:
    You begin by creating a multilingual file that contains terms specific to your organization, such as product names, UI labels, and industry jargon that require consistent translation.
  • Activate the glossary:
    Once you have defined your terminology, you upload it to Intelligent Data Reuse in SAP Translation Hub and activate your glossary.
  • AI-translate your content leveraging your terminology:
    Add your glossary ID to your API call and the approved translations will be applied.

 

Practical Benefits

This approach delivers several concrete advantages for your localization workflow:

  • Lower post-editing volume:
    Because fewer terminology corrections are required after the AI translation is complete, you can focus on other tasks.
  • Consistent terminology:
    Your approved terms will appear consistently across all translated content, reducing variation within a translation project, and across translation projects    .
  • Predictable output:
    The system applies your glossaries systematically, which makes the translation results more predictable and easier to quality-assure.
  • Faster turnaround:
    With less manual correction work needed, your translation cycles can move more quickly through the post-editing phase.

 

Demo

 

 

 

 

 

Watch the recorded demo to see term-aware translation in practice.

 

Implementation Considerations

Term-aware translation works best when your glossaries are well-maintained and contain terms that are actually present in your source content. The overall effectiveness of the feature depends on how comprehensively your glossaries cover the key terminology in your materials.

Please refer to SAP Translation Hub's Document Translation and Intelligent Data Reuse documentation on SAP Help Portal for more details.
